title: 108_s759
content: The Act is titled the "Residential, Farm, Ranch, and Small Business Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" or the "Small Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003." It introduces a credit for residential small wind energy systems under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows a 30% tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures made by individuals. The credit is capped at $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity and requires safety certifications. Unused credits can be carried forward to the next taxable year. The Act provides a 30% tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures by individuals, capped at $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. The expenditure must be for qualified wind energy property installed on a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence, including installation fees. Qualified wind energy property must be a qualifying wind turbine with a 5-year warranty. The Act offers a 30% tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures by individuals, limited to $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. The property must be installed on a residential dwelling unit in the US and include a qualifying wind turbine with a 5-year warranty. The turbine should have a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less, meet performance standards, and be used for electricity generation. Labor costs for installation and interconnection are also eligible for the tax credit. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property includes labor costs for installation and interconnection. Expenditures for energy storage mediums with functions other than storage are not eligible for the credit. Special rules apply for joint occupancy dwelling units. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property includes labor costs for installation and interconnection. Expenditures for energy storage mediums with functions other than storage are not eligible for the credit. Special rules apply for joint occupancy dwelling units, where individuals are treated as one taxpayer for determining the allowable credit based on their expenditures. Individuals who are tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations or members of condominium management associations are treated as having made their proportionate share of any expenditures of the corporation or association. Individuals in cooperative housing corporations or condominium management associations are considered to have made their share of expenditures. For condominium management associations, it refers to organizations meeting specific requirements for residential condominium projects. Expenditures for qualified wind energy property are allocated based on nonbusiness use and energy generation for sale. The timing and amount of expenditures for such property are specified, with exceptions noted. Expenditures for qualified wind energy property are treated as made when installation is completed and property is used for energy generation. Expenditures in connection with building construction are considered made when the structure is used. The amount of expenditure is the cost incurred. Expenditures financed by subsidized energy financing are not included in determining total expenditures for a dwelling unit. For determining expenditures on a dwelling unit, subsidized energy financing is excluded. The basis adjustment reduces the property's basis by the amount of credit allowed for qualified wind energy property expenditures. This section does not apply to property installed after December 31, 2008. The credit allowed under subsection (a) shall not exceed the amount of tax for the taxable year. The Code of 1986 is amended to limit the tax credit for the taxable year based on the regular tax liability and other credits allowable. Subsection (b) amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. Additionally, Section 3 offers a credit for business installation of small wind energy property. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 defines qualified wind energy property installed before January 1, 2009. It specifies that qualified wind energy property includes qualifying wind turbines installed on farms, ranches, or eligible small businesses in the United States. The property must be owned and used by the taxpayer, have its original use commence with the taxpayer, and carry at least a 5-year limited warranty. The credit for such property placed in service during the taxable year is limited to the lesser of certain amounts. The credit for wind energy property placed in service during the taxable year is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. A qualifying wind turbine is defined as one with a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less meeting performance standards. Safety certifications are required for the credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to specify that the energy percentage for qualified wind energy property is 30 percent, while for other energy property it is 10 percent. Safety certifications are necessary for wind energy property to qualify for the tax credit. The amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2003.
